metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of airborne WiDAS mission in the Linze station-Linze grassland flight zone on Jun. 29, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of airborne WiDAS mission was obtained in the Linze station-Linze grassland flight zone on Jun. 29, 2008.
     Data available for general users include Level-2C data (after geometric, radiometric and atmospheric corrections), Level-1B browse image (after intra-band matchingintra-band) and Level-2B browse image (intra-bandafter registration). The raw data, Level-1A, and data processing parameters were filed; applications would be evaluated prior to access. Data processing started in Aug. 2008 and ended in Apr. 2009, and in Nov. 2009, CCD data were reprocessed to adjust radiometric calibration. 
     The flying time of each route was as follows:

{|
! id 
! flight
! relative height
! starttime
! endtime
! data size
! data state
! data quality
! ground targets 
|-
| 1 || 1#13 || 1500m || 11:44:35 || 11:50:31 ||  90 || processed;complete || good || Pingchuan reservoir 
|-
| 2 || 1#11 || 1500m || 11:55:55 || 12:01:55 || 91 || processed;complete || good || Linze grass station 
|-
| 3 || 1#9_1 || 1500m || 12:06:27 || 12:12:27 || 91 || incomplete || incomplete || Pingchuan reservoir 
|-
| 4 || 1#9_2 || 1500m || 13:01:35 || 13:07:43 || 93 || processed;complete || good || Pingchuan reservoir 
|-
| 5 || 1#7 || 1500m || 12:17:59 || 12:23:59 || 91 || processed;complete || good || desert transit plot 
|-
| 6 || 1#5 || 1500m || 12:28:35 || 12:34:31 || 　90 || processed;complete || good || North-south desert strip 
|-
| 7 || 1#3 || 1500m || 12:39:11 || 12:45:03 || 　89 || processed;complete || good || Pingchuan reservoir 
|-
| 8 || 1#1 || 1500m || 12:50:55 || 12:56:51 || 90 || processed;complete || good || Linze station
|}

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data products processed to Level-2C in remote sensing datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: geometric correction, radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors might cause data quality issues in airborne sensor datasets, specifically those related to cloud cover and sensor calibration?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data quality issues in airborne sensor datasets can be caused by several factors, such as cloud cover obscuring the sensor's view, leading to incomplete or missing data, as seen in the case of flight path 1#9_1. Additionally, sensor calibration errors can occur, requiring corrections, as was done in November 2009 for CCD camera radiation calibration.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data quality and completeness when cloud cover impacts aerial data collection flights?
Causal Consequence.Answer: When cloud cover impacts aerial data collection flights, it can result in incomplete datasets and the need for re-flights to obtain complete data. For example, in the dataset mentioned, one of the flight paths (1#9_1) was affected by cloud shadows, leading to a re-flight (1#9_2) to ensure data quality and completeness. This can increase the time and resources required for data collection and processing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures to geometrically correct, radiometrically calibrate, and atmospherically correct airborne sensor data to prepare it for general user accessibility in remote sensing applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The original data from the airborne WiDAS sensor underwent geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction to be published for general user accessibility. The data processing occurred from August 2008 to April 2009, and a CCD camera radiometric calibration correction was made in November 2009.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technological processes enable the production of Level-2C products from airborne remote sensing data in the context of integrated remote sensing experiments?
Enablement.Answer: The production of Level-2C products from airborne remote sensing data is enabled by processes such as geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. These processes ensure that the data is accurate and suitable for general usage. The dataset includes original data that undergoes these corrections to become Level-2C products, which are then made available to users. Additionally, specific data processing times and correction updates, such as the CCD camera radiometric calibration correction in November 2009, are part of the enabling conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the data processing techniques employed for airborne WiDAS sensor data, focusing on geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction methods used in the field.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing techniques for airborne WiDAS sensor data include geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. The processed data products available to users are Level-2C, which have undergone geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. Additionally, quick-look images at Level-1B and Level-2B (inter-band registration) are available. The original data, referred to as Level-1A, and the processing parameters are archived and require an application and approval to access. The processing period was from August 2008 to April 2009, with a correction to the CCD camera's radiometric calibration made in November 2009.
